subject: Re: [junit] Global Rule, active for all tests
msgSnippet: I think with rules JUnit could be a very thin execution framework that can have aspects of running and reporting enhanced with interceptors. With JUnit being
messageBody:
I think with rules JUnit could be a very thin execution framework that can
have aspects of running and reporting enhanced with interceptors. With JUnit
being the defacto standard in all IDE's that would be a solid base for
extenders to add their own flavors of testing.

For some reason Daniel nailed pretty much my whole list and I agree with all
of it. I don't share Daniel's talent for terseness so I do what I do best:
Wordspray, with some luck it sheds some more light in some dark corner:

One thing that I can add to Daniel's list is:
* filtering. If you had global rules you could allow extenders to filter the
testrun based on whatever is available, like annotations. It seems to me
like ignore and the recent categories could be implemented this way.
I know that an @ignore(until=<time>) has been suggested before, that kind of
support could easily be implemented with global rules. I have personally
wanted a @pending annotation, with global rules I could just go ahead and
add that one (Ignore until it works, and fail passing tests marked with
@pending. These kind of enhancements are hard to predict and make a "one
solution to satisfy all" but would be easy to do with global rules and JUnit
could remain a thin (but extendable) intersection.


* Another example of reporting would be one that I implemented with a runner
before. To mark the start and end of a test and dump log-statements if the
test fails. That allows tests to be quiet but the statements that were
logged during the testrun would be available upon failure. Custom reporting
and resource housekeeping like this would be the showcase feature for global
rules I think.


Harder to do (I think) but still useful:

* Global rules could also allow some creative configurations of tests:
Lets say that you want to use a special runner for all tests under a certain
package annotated with a certain annotation. If there were a interception
point where the runner is created that would be possible too.

* Customization according to taste: Let's say that I prefer @Given instead
of @Before, @Spec instead of @Test and so on. With a global rule I could
replace the default runner with a custom one (given an interception point
when the runner is created).

In short, I think global rules would be like XMas for JUnit-extenders :)

On Mon, Dec 14, 2009 at 5:02 PM, Daniel Brolund
<daniel.brolund@...>wrote:

> Hi David,
>
> Some examples:
> * Custom reporting (bumblebee is one example of this)
> * Metrics (especially timing)
> * Dependency injection into test cases
>
> These are generally achievable in other ways, like in that bumblebee uses
> Suites and parses the strings from the test structure.
>
> However, if these "aspects" were addressed in this more generic "ruly" way,
> I sense that such a JUnit API would separate the JUnit implementation from
> the extensions, much like the Rules does today.
>
> Did that compile?
>
> Cheers
> Daniel
>
>
> On Mon, Dec 14, 2009 at 3:43 PM, David Saff <david@...> wrote:
>
> >
> >
> > I'd like to talk about concrete applications one by one--we pushed
> > hard on method rules because it was so easy to write about 10 useful
> > rules once we were done, and having those useful rules pushed us
> > toward a satisfying design. Once the concrete examples are in hand,
> > we can look at how to generalize.
> >
> > In Bogdan's original case, a RunListener was sufficient. I definitely
> > think that bumblebee is a very interesting use case. What are the
> > others?
> >
> > David
> >
> >
> > On Sun, Dec 13, 2009 at 8:58 AM, Joakim Ohlrogge
> > <joakim.ohlrogge@... <joakim.ohlrogge%40gmail.com>> wrote:
> > > I think that it would address a crosscutting concern of the run. Pretty
> > much
> > > like aspects work. This way you could enrich the test-run by
> > declaratively
> > > hooking into the execution. Having global rules you could for instance,
> > > given a match-criteria selects points in the run to hook into.
> > >
> > > How about "declaratively enhance" as a meaning?
> > >
> > > Whatever implementation you choose I have the following wishes based on
> > > working with bumblebee and trying to do these kind of global
> > enhancements:
> > >
> > > * That I do not /have to/ run the tests via a specific suite to have my
> > > global rules applied. The reason is that it's sometimes desirable to
> run
> > > only one test and it would be nice if that test is enhanced in the same
> > way
> > > it would be if run via the suite.
> > >
> > > * That I would not have to add anymore information than can be found on
> > the
> > > class path. The reason is that needing specific configuration such as
> > system
> > > properties or environment variables would make my tests harder to run.
> > >
> > > I have often wanted to make this kind of global rules and I think that
> > > having the possibility would open up for a host of new ways to
> creatively
> > > enhance JUnit. Tools such as bumblebee being one of many things that
> > would
> > > be simple to do given such a feature. I hooked into a suite to capture
> > > System.out for bumblebee documentation and it works well given that I
> run
> > > via that suite. If I don't run via that suite I have experienced hard
> to
> > > debug problems.

> > >> > > Hi everyone,
> > >> > >
> > >> > > as we have it currently, we can place a Rule in a test, and that
> > rule
> > >> will be activated for that test. To have the rule working in several
> > tests,
> > >> you have to place the Rule in each test.
> > >> > >
> > >> > > However, I am searching for a way to activate a Rule for all the
> > tests
> > >> that are executed, without needing to add the rule to each test.
> Perhaps
> > by
> > >> specifying a Java property parameter when running the tests (I could
> > also
> > >> set this as a global Java option, therefore being used upon each
> > execution
> > >> of the JVM).
> > >> > >
> > >> > > Do you know if this is possible?
> > >> > >
> > >> > > The reason why I need this, is: I am making the plans and
> gathering
> > the
> > >> ideas for creating a simple Swing application that will display the
> > results
> > >> of the executed tests (just like the JUnit view in
> > Eclipse/Idea/Netbeans,
> > >> but perhaps with more details, and also available for anyone, not just
> > IDE
> > >> users). Currently I developed a small agent rule, that you can place
> in
> > your
> > >> test, and it will report to the console the status of your tests (the
> > Swing
> > >> console runs remotely).
> > >> > >
> > >> > > This is ok, but it means that you will have to add this rule to
> each
> > >> and every test that you have. It also means that will not be an easy
> > task to
> > >> disable this rule, if you don't want it anymore.
> > >> > >
> > >> > > Therefore a possibility to enable Rules globally for all tests I
> > think
> > >> is the best solution for my case, and also a good tool to have for
> > various
> > >> other tasks.
> > >> > >
> > >> > > What do you think? Also, what do you think about the Swing console
> > >> idea?
> > >> > >
> > >> > > Cheers,
> > >> > > Bogdan
